When Jove spread his convexed Canopie</br>Of constant azure, arched low and high,</br>Did twinckling tapers infinitely set,</br>Where cloud, nor freckle, could their lustre let,</br>But that those seven great Lamps which ever turn,</br>Might every where fling light as round they journ,</br>Forc'd by that wheele which moveth all the rest,</br>With, and against each other, to contest,</br>In that long dance of number, tune, and time,</br>Which by proportion doth joyne, and dis-joyne,</br>Of friendly hatred, loving so, and hate,</br>As wisedome knowes to reconcile the bate</br>Of these strange combatants, which rise, and fall,</br>In their continuall battell cubicall,</br>Which to the circular well reconcil'd</br>Makes, that to unity they gladly yeild.</br>Which when he saw so good, and well agree,</br>He bid th' whole Choire sound out their harmony,

Whereof the seven tones to that one of eight,</br>Sent whole, and halfe tunes by measure and weight,</br>Yea fifths, and thirds, and so a fourth did sound,</br>A second, and a sixt, so well compound,</br>As thereof rang the sweetest melodie,</br>That rule, and order breed, to amitie.

Wherefore the Chorus 'mid th' etheriall Hall,</br>Diffusing all those concords musicall,</br>Did so rejoyce all kinds, each sexe and age,</br>(Invited guests unto that middle stage)</br>As vouch'd on all sides, truth t' own selfe conformes,</br>As vertue demonstrates by all her normes;</br>Whence not to fall, stands where the first belong'd,</br>Still to that mistery to correspond.

Wherein Jove stood rapt, sith this unisone</br>Meerly deriv'd but from one radick tone,</br>Deign'd for it selfe, it selfe to glorifie,</br>Into that multiplying Euphonie,</br>That never ceasing, warbled in that frame</br>That can none other doe then still the same.
O noblest consonance!  O excellence!</br>In which truth breeds love, justice, innocence.

Now to concomitate this Musicks feast,</br>Made to the middle, high, and lowest guest,</br>Jove of those three call'd one out, at whose cry,</br>Averdi came (his daughter) instantly;</br>A Lady truly whiter then the snow,</br>More humble, meek, and mild, then Doves below;</br>More pure, subtill, acute, then clearest aire,</br>More swift then sight, of kind most debonaire.

Goe candor (said he) make thine ayrie flight,</br>Downe through the fiery Region, and enlight</br>With notion generall some above the rest,</br>But thereto make choise of the lowliest,</br>Select of Nations, th' acies of whose mind,</br>Shall to my limits stand by me confin'd;</br>So as though they in part doe know the right,</br>Yet future ages shall receive more light;</br>When Mee list some more speciall ones inspire</br>With knowledge; whilest others shall delire,</br>Til one particular much more shall know,</br>For knowledge but successively shall grow.

Averdi thus dispatch'd with science rare,</br>Her purport of three Regions to declare,</br>The winged Graces (flie she low, or high)</br>Her wayes enlightned with their radii;</br>So did the Classick Vertues lovingly</br>Amid them all still beare her company.

When loe, Delfisa to prevent her, lay,</br>If possibly by any wile she may;</br>About whom, Phantasmes infinite did swarme,</br>Dreames to intoxicate with windy barme,</br>Vaine apparitions, strong imaginations,</br>Conceits, opinions, mad inaugurations,</br>Formes, fancies, figures, fables improbable,</br>Untopicall, unsalted, fond, unstable,</br>Such as the Spirits of th' aire (loos'd to elusion)</br>Have to confound with (making their intrusion)</br>Where, soothly false suborne in steed of true,</br>To be imbib'd by the phanatick crew;</br>And now to bob Averdies negotiation,</br>She featly coyn'd an art of emulation,</br>By stealing to her selfe Averdies shade,</br>Which from the ground did off her light evade,</br>In which she strove her to assimilate,</br>Yet but as shades true bodies imitate;</br>Still plotting her but so to counterfeit,</br>As truth's name, forme, gaine hers be by excheat</br>Of contradiction:  which opposing ever,</br>No meane hath to assigne to own endeavour,</br>But that malengin (woven into faction)</br>Might profit wring out b'others rais'd detraction;</br>For envy never ceaseth to deprave,</br>Till others properties she seize and have.

Yet when Auroraes calm serenitie,</br>Had burnish'd Titans rosie visnomie,</br>And so set up her glasse, as might appeare,</br>All tamskipp prospectives, both far, and neare;</br>Downe soar'd Averdi by her winding staire,</br>On wings display'd, (compos'd of fire, and aire,)</br>Which beare her on that mild amenitie,</br>That all inferiours viewd with singlest eye,</br>All longilatitudes, altitudes eke,</br>Degrees, and what else reason hath to seeke;</br>Each peopled Nation, climate, hot, cold, meane,</br>Th' intemperate, and the temperate, foule and cleane,</br>Where, after her made universall flight,</br>As well around the globe, mid, crosse, and right,</br>She did o're Caldie, then o're Aegypt soare,</br>Where, did on some her meek, elixir poure,</br>Whereof, a gentle, meeke, mild flame, did tine</br>That furor, which their spirits up rapt divine,</br>To contemplate in singlest extasie,</br>Hid speculation from the proudest eye,</br>As yet Astronomie recordth well,</br>And Geometrie, who first did them revell,</br>Yea sow'd the first seeds of Philosophy,</br>By some, with paine, and cost, sought far, and nigh,</br>Their candle to illumin at that light.

But this the more enrag'd Delfisaes spight,</br>Who, coasting neere Averdi, as her shade,</br>On wings of all mixt colours, fraud had made,</br>Did there her malarts phiols drench out pour,</br>On such as would become her Paramour;</br>Whereof, arose most noysome pestilence,</br>Which soone infected scient sapience;</br>A worser pestilence was never known,</br>Then science turn'd into opinion:</br>Which caus'd the Arts themselves, with grief confesse,</br>They wayv'd yet further off from perfectnesse,</br>Malarts encreasing, yea sophisticating</br>Into confusion, all her gulls mistaking.

Which made such garboile of disunion,</br>As for that cause, Averdi got her gone.</br>Meane time, grim night, setting both feet aground,</br>Shov'd the Suns coach-wheels, til he turn'd them round</br>(Which none else could in all the world displace)</br>From th' east, to run his sweaty westerne race;</br>Tho higher mounted, borne on wings of light,</br>Light, her inclosing from those left i' th night,</br>She cross'd the tranquill Medeterranean Sea,</br>O're which, with long delight somnes did plea,</br>Some other Lands in prospective to skrie,</br>Which should, or would, with more gratuitie,</br>Accept her pure Elixirs highest boone,</br>Attempred prudent (reasons wisest doome.)

From whence, in lofty point, to Greece she bore,</br>Whose pure aire, sharp wits, most folke yet adore,</br>For that Elixir, which on them she spent,</br>Sith them in knowledge, made more excellent,</br>Well witnss'd in her grave Philosophers,</br>How seriously demean'd her Registers,</br>Ev'n to the perfecting the Sciences,</br>(Choise reasons jewels, Arts strong fortresses;)</br>Through whose sound dialect, they saw to try,</br>Yea to o're-rule falsed Philosophy.</br>For certes, this Elixir had for spell,</br>That boundlesse font of Hopocrene well,</br>Which running to diffuse that liquid fire,</br>(The furent flame that Poets doth inspire)</br>Caus'd, that devotedly they for her sake,</br>Left th' earth, celestiall scopes to underake,</br>Her steps still tracing, beare she ne're so high,</br>Best instanc'd in their ingenuity.

But this, Delfisa never could abide,</br>Nay, all this to pervert, at heele did glide,</br>Where, so her phiol powr'd out on their braine,</br>As in times processe, did their honour staine;</br>For she to their acutenesse, addes such sleight,</br>As wove the characters of vile deceit,</br>Close hidden in her Etymologie,</br>Which in the name, sounds a deceiver slie.</br>An ignominious brand, which staines the more,</br>As balk'd Averdi, for Delfisaes lore,</br>To prove, deceivers playing loose, and fast,</br>So long deceive, till selves deceive at last.

Wherefore Averdi from them all did flie,</br>And left them to their own earn'd obloquie;</br>Then, back her course steer'd, from whence first shee came,</br>Even to the Nations of more hopefull name,</br>Where, her proficient pupils did enlight,</br>By clearer glassing their interior sight,</br>With that same mentall ravishment, folke call</br>Poetick, Uatick, and Propheticall:</br>Whom she inspir'd with her more secret lore</br>To greatest Clerks unknown, (high t' Allegore,)</br>At which, full many fell of ignorance,</br>But the presumptuous most, of arrogance;</br>At whose audaciousnesse, she did but smile,</br>To see them faster in, the more they toile,</br>Yea, thence ne're to be freed, till humbler, they</br>Shall deign implore Averdies remedy:</br>Who, thence to Almaigne, her faire course forth bore,</br>To try if they were capable of her lore;</br>Whom leaden, muddy, harsh, dull-skull'd, she found,</br>Uncivill, fulsome, sick of Bacchus wound,</br>And far beyond the rest intemperate,</br>Needs therefore prudence must escape their pate.</br>For why?  Delfisa there hath beene already,</br>And all intoxicated belking giddy,</br>To croaking frogs, whose tongues shall never rest,</br>While stood suborn'd Averd's Anthagonist,</br>And therefore barring them her quintassence,</br>Left all those mutinous to owne insolence.

To find out Gaul, (far hotter of desire)</br>The sooner caught of one intestine fire,</br>Inconstant libertines, ires rendezvous,</br>At sodaines, esteem'd most dangerous,</br>Immoderate, rash, giddy, turbulent,</br>Hath but to counterfeit the continent;</br>Albeit insinuates humilianist,</br>Most slily playeth proud opinionist.</br>On this, perceiving Delfis had beset her,</br>Averdi soone resolv'd from thence to get her;</br>Impossible it finding, Gaul, Almaine,</br>Should her, on those conditions enetrtaine;</br>And therefore pawn'd, her wandring wings to rest,</br>While limbs more strength get, as they are releast;</br>Till sweaty Phoebus, wending from her sight,</br>Her, with a ruddy congey bode good-night:</br>Which grace, as it presag'd next morning gray;</br>So promis'd, to performe a golden day.

But when Night, blacks had doff't, and put on blew,</br>Blew, mixt with white, compounding a gray hew,</br>Most fit for Phoebus when him chaires in State,</br>All far off prospectives to speculate;</br>Averdi, still as meeke, as calmest day,</br>Then soaring for discovery, every way,</br>Intended her rath Muses to bestow,</br>On some more meet, discreet, and grave below:</br>Far kenning from an high point, Faiery Land,</br>Which sounds encrease, and nourishing, if scan'd,</br>Did there reigne her Elixir, which so wrought,</br>As that folke, rapt in love, this Dame most sought,</br>Whose very light, them strake with admiration,</br>To trace her steps from Nation, into Nation,</br>And Land, to Land, where so she chose to alight,</br>Although it be in Fairy Land she pight.

On top of whose sharp Promontore, her voice</br>Them call'd, who did ascend with merry noise;</br>The chiefest Spire whereof Oneida hight,</br>For beauty famous, strength, and steeples right;</br>Built on a rock, which had on it an hill,</br>That stood for Land-mark, after Sea-mans skill;</br>The Holt whereof, on which Averdi keeps,</br>Belforma Castl'is watred round with deeps,</br>Where, while aloft, in prospective she sate,</br>Whole chirmes of Poets thither congregate,</br>To serve that soveraigne Beauty, which had power,</br>To ravish each observing Paramour:</br>Whose lovely radii so the men distrought,</br>As they were lost, and found in her they sought;</br>So could not but thus her of right define,</br>O Essence appetible, and O Divine</br>Forme!  causing our beginning, being, end,</br>Therefore, thine honour we shall still defend.</br>Thus stood they rapt into her observation,</br>Time, habit, place, resounding th' approbation,</br>Them gave to meditate the Deitie,</br>Express'd in th' exercise of pietie;</br>Then plainly finding, all her parts agree</br>With her own selfe, when they converted be;</br>She like power having, hers to unite so in one,</br>As all their tones resound her unisone:</br>Like so, how ever any species growes,</br>Its every property meets one in close,</br>As simple vertue knoweth to define,</br>Which of all demonstrations is the prime.

Now all these Laureats standing at her gate,</br>Own offices did, and her love dilate,</br>In straines, conceits, and stile alike sublime,</br>As love could ravish nature up divine!</br>Delfisaes Phiol sheds cromatick matter,</br>Exhal'd out of so foule, and muddy water,</br>As caus'd the musick change mood, time, and forme,</br>Into the noise of a tempestuous storme,</br>Of roaring winds, black clouds evaporating,</br>All true proportion quite precipitating,</br>Into foule showers of frogs, that croke black matter,</br>That spewd the seeds of hate (loves violater)</br>Whereof, blood up to th'orses bridles rose,</br>As Poets crying Ruddimane foreshewes;</br>How first ambitious jealousies did grow,</br>'Bout having, who should more then others know;</br>Which to opinion turning, would own doome,</br>Should above all the rest have elbow roome.

Whereat, Averdi could no longer smile,</br>Sith saw their wits britch'd in Delficaes guile,</br>While caus'd them strongly imagine, sh'ad them given</br>Her key of knowledge; where of, them had riven,</br>Off that Analogie, they had afore,</br>So baffling them in the cloud allegore;</br>As once in fall'n, ne're without help gets out,</br>But that Delfis eludes them, bobs, and flout,</br>Till meeker, they submit to reasons lore,</br>Bernardus she non omnia vidit swore.
Wherefore the Poets begg'd Averdi mild,</br>To shew them how Delfis had them beguil'd,</br>While some conceiv'd they serv'd Averd (their dame)</br>But proves quite contrary, and not the same.
At whose long suite, this Comet (signe of grace)</br>Puts off her mask (a meane to cleare her face,)</br>Then, with mild voice, and serious up-cast eye,</br>To Poets only, made this huoncrie.

If any of yee all, (pretending witty)</br>Who have combustions made without this City,</br>Shall now, with this my anagogick key,</br>In accents numbred, hither find the way,</br>And to mine hand, the same back bring me hither,</br>He shall my true Love be, and Lord for ever;</br>But know, as arts in own vocables talke,</br>Thereby till known, invisiblie to walke,</br>So, more hath allegory to transpose,</br>Verbs, phrases, substantives, to mistick glose,</br>From their owne genuinous signification,</br>Therein to tell, yet hide own revelation:</br>Which, if with meeker spirits yee list discern,</br>Yee that shall teach, yee never knew to learn,</br>To weet!  that all presumptuous arrogance,</br>Was, is, and will be mother of ignorance.</br>Whereto, needs not the new-o'rehaughty stile,</br>Lest th' old, look back, on empty cask, and smile,</br>Yet it behoves that learners must belive,</br>Else, passive intellect may poorely thrive.

That said, amongst them all she flung her key,</br>Which, one poore Poet catching, ran away;</br>While all prose-artists vagely ran out after,</br>But missing, snow-blind came, by shame and laughter:</br>Delfisaes Labyrinth so hood-wincking them,</br>As erring tangled, went the same agen.</br>Wherefore yee swans of Thamesis, what say?</br>Which of you hath this anagogick key?</br>For Chaucer, Lidgate, Sydney, Spencer, dead,</br>Have left this riddle harder to be read;</br>But if yee deigne this scandall to remove,</br>Your fame 'bove prose-arts quill-men, all will rove:</br>Then swans of Olbion, sing these strains of peace,</br>That shall make froggish crokers tongues surcease;</br>Averdies Love for Guerdon, is not small,</br>Besides, a Poets Laureat Coronal;</br>Which earning, out will sing the Victors praise,</br>And sound loves triumph to these latter daies,</br>With blessed peace, that welcomes in the bringer,</br>And cheeres up every sad rejoycing singer.

But first, ought sing a song of twelve monthes long,</br>Next, noblest Guy, (righted on others wrong)</br>Then Chaucers Squires lost tale, on his conditions,</br>The second last part of Poetick visions.</br>For in this order ought the legend bee,</br>According to the Muses own decree.

Now then rapt Poets, what have yee to say?</br>To Dame Averdies key, (the Muses way?)</br>If yee deign answer her Alarum, rise!</br>And arme your verse, to win from prose the prize,</br>Sing swans of Thames, that all the world may know,</br>Yee win the golden wreath, from silver Poe;</br>Whose learned Schools, though have not to give wit,</br>Yet wondrous curiously, they polish it:

But high Jehovh, down through his stars distils</br>What his imployed Philomela thrils,</br>In April blith, and May, but ends in June,</br>That other monthly birds, in kind, may tune,</br>But that another Turtle sing before yee,</br>Assures to your inheritance, the glorie.
At that, Delfisa fell into a rage,</br>Till every other hiss'd her off the stage,</br>And kick her oft, after her own intent,</br>Then merrily, as from a banquet, went.</br>
